revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Elaine Paige}} {{pp-blp|small=yes}} {{Use Canadian English|date=February 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Ellen Page | image = Ellen Page by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Page at the 2013 San Diego Comic Con International | birth_name = Ellen Grace Philpotts-Page | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|02|21}} | birth_place = [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]], Canada | occupation = Actress, producer | years_active = 1997–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Emma Portner]]|2018}} | awards = [[List of awards and nominations received by Ellen Page|Full list]] }} '''Ellen Grace Philpotts-Page'''<ref>{{cite web|title=EPISODE #16 ELLEN PAGE! |url=http://www.annafarisisunqualified.com/2016/02/29/episode-16-ellen-page/|date=Feb 29, 2016|accessdate=March 2, 2016}}</ref> (born February 21, 1987)<ref>{{cite web|last1=Douglas|first1=Clare|title=Birthday girl Ellen Page's 10 best tweets|url=http://ca.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/02015022013726/birthday-girl-ellen-page-s-10-best-tweets|publisher=Hello Canada|date=Feb 20, 2015|accessdate=March 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ellen Page Biography|url=http://www.biography.com/people/ellen-page-267545|publisher=Bio|accessdate=March 6, 2015}}</ref> is a Canadian actress. Her career began with roles in Canadian television shows including ''[[Pit Pony (TV series)|Pit Pony]]'', ''[[Trailer Park Boys]]'', and ''[[ReGenesis]]''. Page starred in the 2005 drama ''[[Hard Candy (film)|Hard Candy]]'', for which she won the [[Austin Film Critics Association]]'s Award for Best Actress. Her breakthrough role was the title character in [[Jason Reitman]]'s comedy film ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'' (2007), for which she received nominations for [[Academy Award]], [[BAFTA]], [[Golden Globe]] and [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] for Best Actress, and won awards including the [[Independent Spirit Award]], [[MTV Movie Awards|MTV Movie Award]] and [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Actress - Comedy|Teen Choice Award for Best Actress Comedy]].
Page portrayed [[Kitty Pryde]] in the [[X-Men (film series)|''X-Men'' series of films]]. She also appeared in the crime-drama film ''[[An American Crime]]'' (2007); the drama ''[[The Tracey Fragments (film)|The Tracey Fragments]]'' (2007), a role that won her the [[Vancouver Film Critics Circle Award for Best Actress|Vancouver Film Critics Award for Best Actress]]; ''[[Smart People]]'' (2008); the [[Sports film|sports]]-[[comedy-drama film]] ''[[Whip It (film)|Whip It]]'' (2009); ''[[Super (2010 American film)|Super]]'' (2010); and ''[[Inception]]'' (2010). She also provided the [[voice acting]], [[motion capture]], and likeness for the character Jodie Holmes in the video game ''[[Beyond: Two Souls]]'' (2013).
==Early life== Page was born and raised in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]], the daughter of Martha Philpotts, a teacher, and Dennis Page, a [[graphic designer]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/london_film_festival/article2724719.ece |last=Maher |first=Kevin |title=Ellen Page isn't fazed by her scripts |work=The Times |location=UK |date=October 27, 2007 |accessdate=June 21, 2009 }}</ref> She attended the [[Halifax Grammar School]] until grade 10, spent some time at [[Queen Elizabeth High School (Halifax, Nova Scotia)|Queen Elizabeth High School]], and graduated from the [[Shambhala School]] in 2005. She also spent two years in [[Toronto]], Ontario, studying in the Interact Program at [[Vaughan Road Academy]], along with close friend and fellow Canadian actor [[Mark Rendall]].<ref name="Daily News">{{Cite news |last=Lisk |first=Dean |title=Page making a scene on screen |work=[[The Daily News (Halifax)|The Daily News]] |date=December 20, 2007 |url=http://www.hfxnews.ca/index.cfm?sid=91213&sc=269 |accessdate=January 16, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://style.uk.msn.com/fashion/photos.aspx?cp-documentid=154122201&page=14 |title=Profile: Ellen Page - Entertainment Celebrity Gossip |publisher=MSN Entertainment UK}}</ref> Growing up, Page enjoyed playing with [[action figure]]s and [[tree climbing|climbing trees]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.complex.com/CELEBRITIES/Complex-Women/Ellen-Page |title=Ellen Page Interview |publisher=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]] |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080124130623/http://www.complex.com/CELEBRITIES/Complex-Women/Ellen-Page |archivedate=January 24, 2008 }}</ref>
==Career== [[Image:Ellen Page.jpg|thumb|upright|Page in 2007]] Page first acted in front of the camera in 1997 at age ten in the [[CBC Television|CBC television]] movie ''Pit Pony'', which later spun off into a television series. This led to more roles in several small Canadian films (including ''[[Marion Bridge (film)|Marion Bridge]]'', her first feature film role) and in television series, notably playing Treena Lahey in season two of ''[[Trailer Park Boys]]''. At 16, she was cast in ''[[Mouth to Mouth (2005 British film)|Mouth to Mouth]]'', an independent film shot in Europe. Page starred in the 2005 movie ''[[Hard Candy (film)|Hard Candy]]'' as a young girl who takes a [[pedophile]] hostage, and won praise for "one of the most complex, disturbing and haunting performances of the year."<ref>{{Cite news|first=Claudia |last=Puig |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2006-12-21-kid-oscars-ellen_x.htm |title=Ellen: Manipulates ''Hard Candy'' to great effect |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|location=Mclean, Virginia|date=December 22, 2006 |accessdate=July 12, 2018}}</ref>
Page appeared in ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'' (2006)<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.tn/books?id=CfK0KtPpSgcC&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=ellen+page+role+in+Xmen+the+last+stand&source=bl&ots=j7AiCE-eEk&sig=KJ9cpTYnz_AYPuq_iet4TeIprIg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwifg93stbvWAhWG5iYKHftBAt44ChDoAQhXMAw#v=onepage&q=ellen%20page%20role%20in%20Xmen%20the%20last%20stand&f=false|title=The 21st Century Superhero: Essays on Gender, Genre and Globalization in Film|first1=Richard J. II| last1=Gray|first2=Betty|last2=Kaklamanidou|date=May 26, 2011|publisher=[[McFarland & Company]]|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=9780786487301}}</ref> and ''[[X-Men: Days of Future Past]]'' (2014) as [[Kitty Pryde]], a girl who can walk through walls. In the previous X-Men movies, the part had been used in brief cameos played by other actresses, but never as a main character. Page was nominated for the [[Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie Scene Stealer]] for the role.
Page portrayed the title character in the 2007 film ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]''. Film critic [[A. O. Scott]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' described her as "frighteningly talented"<ref>{{cite news|first=A.O.|last=Scott|authorlink=A.O. Scott|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2007/12/05/movies/05juno.html|title=Seeking Mr. and Mrs. Right for a Baby on the Way|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=New York York Times Company|location=New York City|date=December 5, 2007|accessdate=July 12, 2018}}</ref> and [[Roger Ebert]] said, "Has there been a better performance this year than Ellen Page's creation of Juno? I do not think so."<ref>{{cite news|first=Roger|last=Ebert|authorlink=Roger Ebert|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071213/REVIEWS/712130303|title=Juno|newspaper=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|publisher=[[Sun-Times Media Group]]|location=Chicago, Illinois|date=December 14, 2007|accessdate=July 12, 2018}}</ref> Page was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Actress]], but lost to [[Marion Cotillard]] in ''[[La Vie en Rose (film)|La Vie en Rose]]''. The role, however, did win her more than 20 awards, including a [[Canadian Comedy Awards|Canadian Comedy Award]], an [[Independent Spirit Award]], and a [[Satellite Award]] besides the likes of numerous Critics awards including [[Detroit Film Critics Society]], [[Austin Film Critics Association]] and [[Florida Film Critics Circle]].
Page also co-starred in ''[[Smart People]]'', which premiered at the 2008 [[Sundance Film Festival]]. Shot before ''Juno'', but released afterwards, the film saw her playing overachieving daughter to [[Dennis Quaid]]{{'s}} college professor.<ref>{{Cite video|people=Noam Muro |title=Smart People |medium=dvd |publisher=Mirmax |year=2008}}</ref> Page's other film credits include ''[[An American Crime]]'', which premiered at the 2007 Sundance Film Festival; ''[[The Tracey Fragments (film)|The Tracey Fragments]]'', which was released in November 2007 in Canada and May 2008 in the US; and ''[[The Stone Angel (film)|The Stone Angel]]''.
In 2007, she was attached to play the [[Jane Eyre (character)|title character]] in an adaptation of [[Charlotte Brontë]]{{'s}} ''[[Jane Eyre]]''<ref name="Jane Eyre">{{Cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117985166.html |title=Ellen Page takes on ''Jane Eyre'' |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=May 6, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=60206 |title=Fukunaga Boards Jane Eyre Remake |publisher=ComingSoon.net |date=October 20, 2009 |accessdate=November 30, 2010}}</ref> and had planned to work on an as-yet unmade film entitled ''Jack and Diane'' opposite [[Olivia Thirlby]], with whom she co-starred in ''Juno'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/19/movies/19lim.html?pagewanted=all |title=Independently Intimate Directors|date=April 15, 2009 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=June 21, 2009 |first=Dennis |last=Lim}}</ref> but it was announced in August 2009 that her role in ''Jack and Diane'' would be played by the actress [[Alison Pill]]. Before his death in January 2008, [[Heath Ledger]] had discussed with Page the idea of starring in his directorial debut, ''The Queen's Gambit''.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Cazzulino |first=Michelle |url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,23446583-5015791,00.html |title=Heath Ledger's gambit to be a director | The Daily Telegraph |publisher=News.com.au |date=March 29, 2008 |accessdate=April 19, 2009}}</ref>
In 2008, she was ranked #86 on ''[[FHM]]''{{'s}} [[FHM's 100 Sexiest Women (UK)|Sexiest Women in the World]] list, and placed at #93 for 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/ellen-page|title=FHM: Ellen Page|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114075129/http://www.fhm.com/girls/covergirls/ellen-page|archivedate=November 14, 2012}}</ref> In June 2008, Page was listed in ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'s}} future A-List stars list.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20205050_5,00.html|title=Ellen Page {{!}} 15 to Watch: Hollywood's Next A-List | work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref> Page hosted ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' on March 1, 2008.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Collins |first=Leah |url=http://www.canada.com/globaltv/globalshows/et_story.html?id=02578fa4-fab5-4510-a68d-dba949e50f18 |title=Ellen Page tapped for SNL, Walters special |work=canada.com |date=February 12, 2008 |accessdate=February 15, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602155301/http://www.canada.com/globaltv/globalshows/et_story.html?id=02578fa4-fab5-4510-a68d-dba949e50f18 |archivedate=June 2, 2008 }}</ref> On May 3, 2009, she guest starred in the episode "[[Waverly Hills 9-0-2-1-D'oh]]" of the animated series ''[[The Simpsons]]'' as a character named Alaska Nebraska, a parody of [[Hannah Montana]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2008-09-24-simpsons-20th-season_N.htm |title='The Simpsons' hits a landmark |work=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=September 25, 2008 |date=September 25, 2008 |first=Bill |last=Keveney}}</ref> She also starred in Drew Barrymore's directorial debut, ''[[Whip It (film)|Whip It]]'', alongside [[Juliette Lewis]], [[Marcia Gay Harden]], [[Drew Barrymore]] and [[Kristen Wiig]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cast-ready-roll-whip-114770 |title=Cast ready to roll on ''Whip It!'' |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=June 29, 2008 |accessdate=April 19, 2009}}</ref> The film premiered at the 2009 [[Toronto International Film Festival]] and had its wide release on October 2, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1172233/ |title=Whip It! (2009) |publisher=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref>
[[File:InceptionCastPremiereJuly10.jpg|thumb|left|Page (center) with the cast of ''[[Inception]]'' at the premiere in July 2010|alt=A photograph of the cast of the 2010 film ''Inception'', including Ellen Page in the middle]]
She featured in Michael Lander's film ''[[Peacock (2009 film)|Peacock]]'', opposite [[Cillian Murphy]], [[Susan Sarandon]], [[Bill Pullman]] and [[Josh Lucas]], which was released in 2010 despite an original release date of 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Siegel |first=Tatiana |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117980955.html |title=Page, Murphy set for 'Peacock' |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=February 14, 2008 |accessdate=February 14, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1188113/ |title=Peacock (2009) |publisher=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref> In August 2009, Page began shooting the big-budget [[Christopher Nolan]] thriller ''[[Inception]]'', alongside co-stars [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Marion Cotillard]], [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]] and [[Ken Watanabe]].<ref>{{Cite news|last=Fleming |first=Michael |url=http://www.variety.com/VR1118002026.html |title=Trio in talks for 'Inception' |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=April 19, 2009 |date=April 1, 2009}}</ref> The film was released on July 16, 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Inception|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=inception.htm|accessdate=November 10, 2012|newspaper=Box Office Mojo}}</ref> She has starred in the film ''Super'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Kay |first=Jeremy |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/rainn-wilson-ellen-page-liv-tyler-join-super-for-ted-hope/5005525.article |title=Rainn Wilson, Ellen Page, Liv Tyler join Super for Ted Hope | News | Screen |publisher=Screendaily.com |date=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=November 30, 2010}}</ref> and was announced to be playing Stacie Andree in a film about [[Laurel Hester]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2008/12/24/ellen_page_to_play_lesbian |title=Ellen Page To Play Lesbian |accessdate=January 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210163541/http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2008/12/24/ellen_page_to_play_lesbian |archivedate=February 10, 2009 }}</ref> finally released in 2015 as ''[[Freeheld (film)|Freeheld]]''.
[[File:Adorable Ellen Page at the 2013 San Diego Comic Con International -a.jpg|thumb|230px|Page at the [[San Diego Comic-Con International]] in July 2013]]
As of 2010, she serves as a spokesperson for [[Cisco Systems]] in a series of advertisements, appearing in three commercials set in [[Lunenburg, Nova Scotia]]. On May 26, 2010, it was reported in a column on ''[[Deadline Hollywood]]'' and by ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' that Page would star in the HBO series ''Tilda'' alongside [[Diane Keaton]], who was cast in the lead role. ''Tilda'' is based on the life of [[Nikki Finke]], the founder of the influential Hollywood blog, DeadlineHollywood.com.<ref>{{cite web|first=Nellie |last=Andreeva|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/05/diane-keaton-ellen-page-in-hbos-tilda/ |title=Diane Keaton & Ellen Page In HBO's 'Tilda' – |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=May 26, 2010 |accessdate=November 30, 2010}}</ref> ''Tilda'' was reportedly dropped by HBO due to friction between the creators.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Lacey |last=Rose |title=HBO Passes on Hollywood Blogger Comedy 'Tilda' |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hbo-passes-hollywood-blogger-comedy-161441 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 25, 2011|accessdate=March 19, 2011}}</ref> She is also the narrator of the documentary on [[colony collapse disorder]], ''[[Vanishing of the Bees]]'', directed by [[Maryam Henein]].
In April 2011, it was announced that Page would co-star in the [[Woody Allen]] film ''[[To Rome with Love (film)|To Rome with Love]]'' alongside [[Jesse Eisenberg]], [[Penélope Cruz]], and [[Alec Baldwin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitfix.com/articles/ellen-page-jesse-eisenberg-alec-baldwin-join-woody-allen-film|title=Ellen Page, Jesse Eisenberg, Alec Baldwin join Woody Allen film|website=[[Hitflix]]|date=April 13, 2011}}</ref> In June 2012, [[Quantic Dream]] announced a [[video game]] entitled ''[[Beyond: Two Souls]]'' in which Page and [[Willem Dafoe]] portray the protagonists Jodie Holmes and Nathan Dawkins, respectively. It was released on October 8, 2013, in North America.<ref>{{cite web |first=Dave |last=Tach|url=https://www.theverge.com/gaming/2012/6/7/3071315/beyond-two-souls-impress-with-its-blend-of-narrative-and-technology |title='Beyond: Two Souls' impresses with its blend of narrative and technology |work=The Verge |date=June 7, 2012 |accessdate=June 9, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Martin |last=Robinson|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2012-06-05-quantic-dreams-beyond-confirmed-ellen-page-onboard |title=Quantic Dream's Beyond confirmed, Ellen Page onboard |work=eurogamer.net |date=June 5, 2012 |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2013/03/01/willem-dafoe-ellen-page-star-in-beyond-two-souls-october-8th |title=Willem Dafoe, Ellen Page Star in BEYOND: Two Souls October 8th |publisher=Playstation.com |last=Osgood|first=Derek |date=March 1, 2013 |accessdate=June 25, 2013}}</ref> Page reprised her role as Katherine "Kitty" Pryde in ''[[X-Men: Days of Future Past]]'' (2014).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/26/x-men-days-of-future-past-cast-ellen-page-anna-paquin-shawn-ashmore_n_2558977.html |title='X-Men: Days of Future Past' Cast: Ellen Page, Anna Paquin, Shawn Ashmore Added To Roster |work=Huffington Post |date=January 26, 2013 |accessdate=January 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/BryanSinger/status/295265552375631872|date=January 26, 2013|title=Very excited to welcome #annapaquin, @ellenpage & @shawnrashmore to #XMen #DaysofFuturePast |first=Bryan|last=Singer}}</ref> In February 2013, Page confirmed that her directorial debut would be titled ''[[Miss Stevens]]'' and would star [[Anna Faris]] and be produced by [[Gary Gilbert]], [[Jordan Horowitz]] and Doug Wald;<ref>{{cite web |first=Josh L.|last=Dickey| title = Ellen Page set for directorial debut with ‘Miss Stevens’ |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118065853/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 7, 2014|accessdate=February 8, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Mike Jr.|last=Fleming|title=Ellen Page Making Directing Debut On ‘Miss Stevens’; Anna Faris To Star|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/02/ellen-page-making-directing-debut-on-miss-stevens-anna-faris-to-star/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 7, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013}}</ref> the project eventually moved forward without Page, with scriptwriter Julia Hart replacing Page as the director.<ref name=B>{{cite web|first=Patrick|last=Hipes|url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/lily-rabe-miss-stevens-mark-obrien-story-of-your-life-frank-the-bastard-1201453130/|title=Lily Rabe To Star In Indie ‘Miss Stevens’; Mark O’Brien Joins ‘Story Of Your Life’; ‘Frank The Bastard’ Gets July Release|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=June 24, 2015|accessdate=January 26, 2016}}</ref> In December 2014, Page portrayed [[Han Solo]] in a staged reading of ''[[Star Wars Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back]]''.<ref>{{cite web |first=Sean|last=O'Neal|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/ellen-page-han-solo-jessica-alba-princess-leia-jas-213205 |title=Ellen Page is Han Solo, Jessica Alba is Princess Leia for Jason Reitman’s live read |website=[[The A.V. Club]] |publisher=Onion, Inc.|location=San Francisco, California|date=December 18, 2014 |accessdate=December 23, 2014}}</ref>
Page co-starred in [[Zal Batmanglij]]'s 2013 thriller film ''[[The East (film)|The East]]'' a movie inspired by the experiences and drawing on thrillers from the 1970s, alongside [[Brit Marling]] and [[Alexander Skarsgård]]; Page replaced [[Felicity Jones]], who had been attached to the project, but later dropped out.<ref>{{cite web|first=Jen|last=Yamato|url=http://movieline.com/2013/01/21/sundance-the-east-freegan-brit-marling-zal-batmanglij/|title=[VIDEO] ‘The East’ – Freegan Summer Inspired Anarchist Thriller - Movieline|work=Movieline}}</ref> The same year she starred in [[Lynn Shelton]]'s ''[[Touchy Feely]]'' alongside [[Rosemarie DeWitt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2364949/awards?ref_=tt_awd|title=Touchy Feely|date=March 1, 2014|publisher=|via=IMDb}}</ref> Page starred in the film ''[[Tallulah (film)|Tallulah]]'' alongside her ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'' costar, [[Allison Janney]],<ref>{{cite web |first= Jeff|last= Sneider|url= http://www.thewrap.com/junos-ellen-page-allison-janney-to-reteam-for-dramatic-comedy-tallulah/ |title='Juno's' Ellen Page, Allison Janney to Reteam for Dramatic Comedy 'Tallulah' |work=thewrap.com |date= May 20, 2015|accessdate=June 30, 2015}}</ref> and had two other releases slated for 2015, Canadian drama film ''[[Into the Forest]]'' and [[Peter Sollett]]'s ''[[Freeheld (2015 film)|Freeheld]]''.<ref>{{cite web|first=Justin|last=Kroll|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/gabriel-luna-matador-casting-ellen-page-1201324881/|title=‘Matador’s’ Gabriel Luna Joins Ellen Page in ‘Freeheld’|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=October 8, 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== In 2008, Page was one of 30 celebrities who participated in an online ad series for [[US Campaign for Burma]], calling for an end to the military dictatorship in [[Burma]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/04/fashion/04myanmar.html |title=Trying to Put a Name to the Face of Evil | work=[[The New York Times]] | first=Alex | last=Williams | date=May 4, 2008 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}}</ref> She describes herself as a [[pro-choice]] [[Feminism|feminist]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/15/AR2008021500818.html |title='People always see a movie and project how you're going to be.' | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=February 17, 2008 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}}</ref> She attended [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] school in her youth and practised [[meditation]] and [[yoga]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hollowverse.com/ellen-page/|title='Ellen Page's Religion and Political Views}}</ref> She practices a [[vegan]] lifestyle, and [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] named her and [[Jared Leto]] the Sexiest Vegetarians of 2014.<ref>Olivia Waxman, "[http://time.com/2928418/sexiest-vegetarian-peta-jared-leto-ellen-page/ Jared Leto and Ellen Page Are PETA's Sexiest Vegetarian Celebrities]," ''Time'', June 26, 2014.</ref> She is an atheist.<ref>Daniel D'Addario, "[http://time.com/4001823/ellen-page-freeheld/ Ellen Page on Freeheld and Why She Came Out: ‘I Was Just Depressed’]," ''Time'', August 27, 2015.</ref>
On February 14, 2014, Page [[coming out|came out]] as gay<!--"gay" vs "lesbian" discussed in 1st archive of talk page--> during a speech at the [[Human Rights Campaign]]'s "Time to Thrive" conference in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/ellen-page-comes-as-gay-680563 |title=Ellen Page Comes Out As Gay: 'I Am Tired of Lying by Omission' (Exclusive) | work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | first=Seth | last=Abramovitch | date=February 14, 2014 | accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref><ref name="CBC_News_2014-02-14">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/canadian-actress-ellen-page-comes-out-as-gay-i-m-tired-of-hiding-1.2538384|title=Canadian actress Ellen Page comes out as gay: 'I'm tired of hiding'|date=February 14, 2014|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R3HhIYUtXRY |title=Ellen Page Joins HRCF's Time to Thrive Conference | work=[[Human Rights Campaign]] | date=February 14, 2014 | accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref> In 2014, she was included as part of ''[[The Advocate]]''{{'}}s annual "40 Under 40" list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/40-under-40-emerging-voices/2014/08/20/40-under-40-megan-ellison-makes-movies-you-talk-about|title=40 Under 40: Megan Ellison Makes the Movies You Talk About - Advocate.com|work=advocate.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Gilchrist|first1=Tracy|title=Ellen Page, This Generation's Gay A-Lister|url=http://www.advocate.com/40-under-40-emerging-voices/2014/08/20/40-under-40-ellen-page-generations-gay-lister|publisher=The Advocate|accessdate=December 29, 2014|date=August 20, 2014}}</ref>
On November 10, 2017, Page alleged that filmmaker [[Brett Ratner]] outed her as gay on the set of ''[[X-Men: The Last Stand]]'', when she was 18 years old, nearly a decade before she came out publicly in 2014.<ref name="accusescbc"/><ref name="ratnerguardian">{{cite news|last1=Levin|first1=Sam|title=Ellen Page says Brett Ratner outed her as gay in sexual remark when she was 18|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/nov/10/ellen-page-brett-ratner-gay-comment|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=November 10, 2017}}</ref> Fellow actress [[Anna Paquin]] expressed support of Page, stating that she was present when Ratner made the comment.<ref name="accusescbc">{{cite news|title=Ellen Page accuses Brett Ratner of sexual harassment|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/entertainment/ellen-page-facebook-ratner-1.4397539|work=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=November 20, 2017}}</ref>
In January 2018, Page married dancer and choreographer [[Emma Portner]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://people.com/movies/ellen-page-married-emma-portner/|title=Surprise! Ellen Page Is Married to Emma Portner|last=Miller|first=Mike|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=January 3, 2018|access-date=January 3, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/theatre-and-performance/ottawa-born-choreographer-emma-portner-challenges-dances-gender-and-artistic-conventions/article36587319/|title=Ottawa-born choreographer Emma Portner challenges dance’s gender and artistic conventions|access-date=February 24, 2018}}</ref>
